original_solution_mapping.L1: Between the trolley driver and his first 10 customers, there are 1+10 = <<1+10=11>>11 people are currently on the trolley
original_solution_mapping.L2: On his first stop, 10 people go on and twice as many people got on at the second stop so 10*2 = <<10*2=20>>20 people got on at the second stop.
original_solution_mapping.L3: So at the second stop he had 11 people on board, 3 got off and 20 got on so he now has 11-3+20 = <<11-3+20=28>>28 people
original_solution_mapping.L4: At his third stop 18 people got off and 2 got on so in total there are 28-18 +2 = <<28-18+2=12>>12 people on the trolley

original_function_code:
def solve():
    """Index: 5496.
    Returns: the number of people currently on the trolley.
    """
    # L1
    initial_customers = 10 # 10 people on his 1st stop
    trolley_driver = 1 # trolley driver
    people_after_first_stop = trolley_driver + initial_customers

    # L2
    multiplier_twice = 2 # twice as many people
    people_on_second_stop = initial_customers * multiplier_twice

    # L3
    people_off_second_stop = 3 # 3 people got off
    people_after_second_stop = people_after_first_stop - people_off_second_stop + people_on_second_stop

    # L4
    people_off_third_stop = 18 # 18 people got off
    people_on_third_stop = 2 # 2 got on
    final_people_on_trolley = people_after_second_stop - people_off_third_stop + people_on_third_stop

    # FA
    answer = final_people_on_trolley
    return answer

logical_steps.solution_line_template: Between the trolley driver and his first {initial_customers} customers, there are {trolley_driver}+{initial_customers} = <<{trolley_driver}+{initial_customers}={people_after_first_stop}>>{people_after_first_stop} people are currently on the trolley

On his first stop, {initial_customers} people go on and twice as many people got on at the second stop so {initial_customers}*{multiplier_twice} = <<{initial_customers}*{multiplier_twice}={people_on_second_stop}>>{people_on_second_stop} people got on at the second stop.

So at the second stop he had {people_after_first_stop} people on board, {people_off_second_stop} got off and {people_on_second_stop} got on so he now has {people_after_first_stop}-{people_off_second_stop}+{people_on_second_stop} = <<{people_after_first_stop}-{people_off_second_stop}+{people_on_second_stop}={people_after_second_stop}>>{people_after_second_stop} people

At his third stop {people_off_third_stop} people got off and {people_on_third_stop} got on so in total there are {people_after_second_stop}-{people_off_third_stop} +{people_on_third_stop} = <<{people_after_second_stop}-{people_off_third_stop}+{people_on_third_stop}={final_people_on_trolley}>>{final_people_on_trolley} people on the trolley

flawed_nl_reconstruction.L1: Between the trolley driver and his first 10 customers, there are 1+10 = <<1+10=11>>11 people are currently on the trolley
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L2: On his first stop, 10 people go on and twice as many people got on at the second stop so 10*2 = <<10*2=20>>20 people got on at the second stop.

explanation: Incorrect final answer. An intermediate value 'people_on_second_stop' (value: 20) was reported instead of 'final_people_on_trolley' (value: 12).
